helful \uD83D\uDC4D

`Tips:-`

It's easy to realise what we need to do here, alternatively put characters with maximum frequency. The problem lies in implementing this.

Even if you get the intuition of using `Heaps`, it's still a tricky one to implement.

So, the trick is to store pair of `{frequency,char}` in a Heap. Then while `Heap.size()>1` , at every iteration, take out the top two elements, append them to the ans string, decrease their frequency by `1` and push them again in the Heap.

When the loop will break, either the Heap became `empty` or of `1 size.`

If it's empty, return the ans string.

if it has `size == 1`, check the remaining frequency of the top/last element, if its `1`, append it and return ans.

Otherwise, return `""`

seemed easy at first... until it wasn\'t
tricky one\n

The approach to solve this problem is to use a priority queue to store the characters based on their frequency. We first count the frequency of each character in the string and store it in a hash map. Then, we create a priority queue and add all the characters from the hash map to it. We use a comparator to order the characters in the priority queue based on their frequency in decreasing order.

Then, we take out two characters from the priority queue and append them to the output string. We keep track of the last character appended to the output string. If the next character in the priority queue is the same as the last character appended to the output string, we take out the next character from the priority queue and append it to the output string. We continue this process until the priority queue is empty or we cannot append any more characters to the output string.

If we cannot append any more characters to the output string, we return an empty string.

what if the question is with minimum numbers of swap done .. the !?? can someone give idea ?
another unlucky day
Its a very good problem for logical thinking!
I never thought this problem could be a problem until it became one by giving me a headache.

Its a great question to think about and implement.
Some tips:

1. Look for the condition where its not possible to make the string at all, that is, if the frequency of any character is greater than (n+1)/2 then its not possible because the number of gaps between these characters would be more than the number of characters left in the string.

2. Once you have taken care of the 'not possible' condition, now you can try to find a way to make the string. There could be multiple ways to do this but the easiest one to implement would be to use a priority queue and append the characters of the two most frequent characters alternatively.
[@sarbajit acharjee](/Noobcoooooder)
I thought we should use the back tracking since the beginning for this type of question. Who can realize this solution in the interview?

the thing about backtracking is the max length of the string is 500. Since we know that the number of characters in the alphabet is 26 and we would have to try a lot of subproblems. I initially thought it was going to be a Dp problem but I realized if I used recursion there are no overlapping subproblems. So I just started writing more examples out.

s = "ogccckcwmbmxtsbmozli"

Output : "czcxcwctmsmlmkoiogbg"

Expected : "cocgcickmlmsmtbwbxoz"

in the description it is written that *Return any possible rearrangement of s or return "" if not possible*
But it is showing wrong ans.
[@siebenschlaefer](/siebenschlaefer) thank you bro got the correct answer!!

`s` and `Output` contain differenct characters. In sorted order:
```py
s:      bbccccgiklmmmoostwxz
output: bccccggiklmmmoostwxz
```
Surely not a medium one \uD83D\uDC80

Its a very good problem for logical thinking!
I never thought this problem could be a problem until it became one by giving me a headache.

Its a great question to think about and implement.
Some tips:

1. Look for the condition where its not possible to make the string at all, that is, if the frequency of any character is greater than (n+1)/2 then its not possible because the number of gaps between these characters would be more than the number of characters left in the string.

2. Once you have taken care of the 'not possible' condition, now you can try to find a way to make the string. There could be multiple ways to do this but the easiest one to implement would be to use a priority queue and append the characters of the two most frequent characters alternatively.

I thought we should use the back tracking since the beginning for this type of question. Who can realize this solution in the interview?

the thing about backtracking is the max length of the string is 500. Since we know that the number of characters in the alphabet is 26 and we would have to try a lot of subproblems. I thought of going with a two pointer approach, and swapping the element with the non repeating one, Like, Eg- xxxab, Then I\'d swap the second occurance of the repeating element with a char which is different than the repeating one. But I cannot what would be a problem in this approach, Can anyone tell?
That is actually exactly how I solved it. You just need to loop through it once going from left to right then once going from right to left.
little tricky one , but solved!!! \n\u2705

Append the most frequent letter to the return string. If the last letter of the return string is the same as the most frequent letter then append the second most frequent letter to the string instead. If there is no second frequent letter then alternation can't be done so return an empty string.
As you append letters, the frequency of the remaining letters decreases and other letters may become more frequent. You will need a priority queue to keep track of the most frequent letters.

little tricky one , but solved!!! \n\u2705

Append the most frequent letter to the return string. If the last letter of the return string is the same as the most frequent letter then append the second most frequent letter to the string instead. If there is no second frequent letter then alternation can't be done so return an empty string.
As you append letters, the frequency of the remaining letters decreases and other letters may become more frequent. You will need a priority queue to keep track of the most frequent letters.
